item.description:
Spindizzy is a mind-boggling game for 3 players that can be played with the Shibumi game system. It uses the 4×4 board, 10 red, 10 black and 10 white balls.

				
					Rules

The board is initially empty.

Players choose a colour and start with 10 balls each.

Then each player passes 3 balls of their supply to the left neighbour, and 2 balls to the right neighbour. From now on, at all times during the game the players keep their balls hidden.

A player is selected to be the "master" of the first turn.

In each turn – at the same time – players secretly pick one of their balls from their supply and hold it – hidden in the closed hand – towards the other players. When all players made their selection, the balls are revealed simultaneously.

Now the colour of the master player’s ball determines which player (remember, each player is assigned a colour) must play the ball in their hand first. A ball may be placed on any empty hole of the board or on any 2×2 platform. Then in clockwise direction the other two players also place their balls.

Whenever a small 5-ball pyramid is formed, the player whose colour represent the majority (or, if there is no clear majority, the player who owns the top ball) scores 1 point.

The last player of the current turn will then be the master player of the next turn.

End of the Game

When the last ball is played and the point is scored, the game ends. The player with the highest score wins the game. In the case where 2 players are tied, the third player wins.

Included in the Shibumi Rule Book

Soft cover:

http://www.lulu.com/shop/cameron-browne-and-nestor-romeral-andres/shibumi-rule-book/paperback/product-18940123.html

Downloadable PDF:

http://www.nestorgames.com/rulebooks/SHIBUMI_EN.pdf

The Mafia has never been stronger: assaults, ambushes, and smuggling are happening throughtout the streets. But the police is not playing around! Infiltrated police officers will attempt to sabotage Mafia missions at all costs to show who's the real boss of the city

At the beggining of the game, players receive secret goals: mafia or police. The first ones should complete the missions, while te second ones should force them to fail (secretly). When 4 missions have suceeded or failed, the game ends.

During the whole game, 2 missions remain open at the table, and different characters are assigned to them.
Each mission has a number value, a color and a quanitity of cards necessary to complete it.
Players who are at the mission can contribute (or not) to it by secretly playing action cards at it.

All action cards may be used to contribute for missions or may be used as an action. There is a wide variety of actions, such as adding or removing a character from a mission, buying more cards, forcing a player to lose cards, block a player's turn, etc.. but remember:
In the underworld of MAFIA, you never know whom you can trust!

name.value: Teleprompter: Cyphers of the Spiritual Hinterlands

item.description:
1. Players agree to play to a number of points. 
2. The players take turns being the Teleprompter.
2. The Teleprompter first chooses a number of receivers equal to half the number of players rounded down and describes a situation that the first player has caused through supernatural means. The situation is actually an enciphered message to the receiving players. The Teleprompter chooses a number of guesses: 1-3, inclusive, for the round. 
3. A non-receiver is allowed to guess what the message means. Then, a receiver is allowed to guess. Then, a non-receiver is allowed to guess. The two groups alternate trying to figure out the message until either:
 a. someone figures out the message or
 b. everyone (save the originator of the message) has the opportunity to guess the predetermined number of times determined in step 2.
4. If 3a occurs and a receiver is the correct guesser, the Teleprompter and the receiver who guesses correctly each get a point. If a non-receiver is the correct guesser, then the non-receiver gets two points. If no-one guesses correctly, then the Teleprompter loses a point. It is not possible to have negative points.
5. The first player to the predetermined number of points wins. There can be ties.

The Galaxy Corporate is a world of trading and piracy for two to four players. Players amass influence by buying planets and trade outposts (or taking them by force) in their quest to become the largest corporation in the galaxy.

A unique economy system combines with a modular board to provide a different galaxy with every game. The laws of supply and demand force players to turn simple buying and selling into strategic economic weapons. Real weapons are also available in the form of ship upgrades and mercenary vessels to turn rivalries hostile.

Will you be a peaceful trading baron or bloodthirsty pirate? The choice is yours in the Galaxy Corporate.

Olympicards has the player athletes compete in nine different events, with competition taking place via card play. Each sport has its own rules for playing cards, so sometimes you'll want to sit out an event to conserve your strength, while other times you'll push yourself to the limit to win the gold.

Each player starts the game with six cards, each card having a number and color. On a turn, you'll play one or two cards until you cannot – or don't want to – play any more cards. The first player to drop from the event receives more cards for next time, while whoever remains in the event until the end wins the gold medal (i.e. points).

Whoever has the most points after nine events wins!

item.description:
Old Century Pinball Golf Wood Wooden Table Top Pinball Machine (Game)

Swing down the fairways of the legendary courses as you relive the golden era of golf. Make a birdie or score the elusive hole-in-one -- but watch out for the sand traps and water hazards!

An heirloom quality coffee table game, Pinball Golf provides fun for everyone, from grandparents to grand kids.


 Archival quality coffee table game



 Classic look and feel reminiscent of the golden era of golf



 Great addition to any golf collection 



 Authentic fun for the whole family


Features: hole progress track (golf tee pinhole track), convenient ball return, club shaped flipper, challenging hazards, a hole-in-one ramp

These wonderfully low-tech "Coffee Table Games" will provide hours of authentic fun. Powered only by imagination and enthusiasm, these high quality games and toys connect people, young and old, through play. Old Century Classics' unique designs and innovative interpretations of game and toy classics set a new standard for shared fun and laughter.

Boo! You and your friends are suddenly surrounded by hordes of very aggressive zombies. But do not fret as we have some good news – one of you will definitely get out alive. How can you become that lucky person? It's simple! As the old saw goes, you don't have to outrun the zombies; you just need to outrun your friends.

At the start of Zombie! Run for Your Lives! each player receives four cards from the deck; cards are one of two types: a zombie (which come in different varieties) or a potentially helpful item that can protect you from those aforementioned zombies. The different types of zombies and the items that affect them are color-coded and bear identical symbols for easy recognition.

On a turn, you draw a card from the deck, then play a card from your hand, sending a zombie after one of the other players or using an item to help yourself; if the item matches a zombie card in front of you, both cards are discarded. A player cannot have identical items or zombies in front of him. If you ever have five zombies in front of you, you've succumbed to the horde and become a zombie yourself. As a result, your mental abilities are extremely limited, which means that on your turn, you simply draw the top card and play it on a living player, getting revenge against whoever killed you or perhaps aiding the player you care for the most.

If, on the other hand, you collect five items in front of yourself, you've proved yourself invulnerable to zombies and instantly win!

item.description:
SOLO BALONCESTO is a two-player boardgame that recreates a real basketball match. Each player is one of the two teams facing-up coaches. Two teams with 10 players each, where you can choose your "starting lineup" on the court:


 point guards
 shooting guards
 small forwards
 power forwards
 centers


 
Each player has 5 different skills: Passing - action points - play skill - height - scoring %.
 You have full control of the whole team, which will allow you to perform any individual action with any player on the court. A joint action between two players like a screen or a "pick& roll", a team tactic like playing in the zone or a man-to-man defense, faithfully recreating what happens in a basketball game. Thanks to its mechanic, mixes a great realism in the actions with high simplicity. Players move one by one alternating between attacker and defender, not the entire team at once, making play faster. This makes the duration of a turn variable, so you play four quarters like in a real game but not a predetermined number of turns in each quarter.

Passes, rebounds, fouls, two-point shots, lay ups, three-pointers, dunks, freethrows, blocks, pick& roll, steals... any basketball action is possible in this game!

item.description:
"The game with three pieces"

Old Swedish boardgame published by Brio. An abstract strategy game for 2-4 players, it's reminiscent of Halma while also featuring Checkers-like piece elimination using rock-paper-scissors mechanics. Everyone has three pieces: "Hunter", "eagle" and "snake". The goal is to move as many of your pieces as possible across the board. You can move your pieces left, right and forward, but never backwards, and diagonally only when jumping over other pieces. Hunters can kill eagles when jumping, eagles can kill snakes and snakes can kill hunters.

Because of the elimination mechanic, the winner is the player who reaches their target corner with the most pieces remaining (in case of a tie, the one who got there first). Unlike most similar games Trippel also supports a 3-player variant, though no specific rules for this are given.

Likely date of publication: 1950's-'60s.

item.description: 2 Player Deck Building Card Game based on the 1993 PC game. Fan Tribute. One player is X-Com, the other is the aliens. There is no common deck. Each player has their own set of cards to build from. Win by destroying your opponent's main base. As Panic Levels rise X-Com loses resources but gains desperate card trashing options. Depending on what cards players research, strategies can shift from Interception heavy, to Tactical heavy, to Research Heavy.

name.value: JammerUp: The Roller Derby Board Game

item.description:
JammerUp: The Roller Derby Board Game is a turn-based simulation of modern day roller derby. The rules provide an analogue of the sport's rule set, and many of the same strategies and tactics that work on the track apply to the board game. 
 In a 2-player game, each player controls a team of 5 game pawns: four Blockers and one Jammer. A player moves her Jammer through the pack, maneuvering around opposing Blockers, to earn points. At the same time, she must position her own blockers to prevent the opposing Jammer from scoring. Pawn movement is simply defined on a hexagonal grid. Blockers can in a counter-clockwise direction; Jammers can move in any direction at all and may "juke" to get around opposing pieces.

There are two ways to play:

Take Your Chances
Players of the Take Your Chances flavorof the game will enjoy drawing cards that allow them to jump, juke, and block in special ways that help them make their way through the pack and defend their territory.

Pure Strategy
Fans of abstract strategy games will skip the cards and dice, relying purely on their ability to outwit their opponent. They'll learn to master real derby strategies like skating the diamond, hammer & nail, and goating.
 The game ships with a board, 10 plastic skater pawns, 2 scoring winks, cards, die, and rule book. Optional glass pawns and pewter miniatures are sold separately.

A second game by the Church Missionary Society, educating people about their work around the world.

The game is played rather like Happy Families in that you must ask a player of your choice for a card from a set that you already a card in that set. Eventually all 12 sets will have been completed. Now the game uses its educational purpose as players need to know something about the territory related to a set. Reference sheets are provided for the sort of information required. If information is not forthcoming, or the information provided is incorrect, the player loses that set. This continues until all sets have been 'challenged' and the winner of the game is the player with the most sets.

From the rules:

Players each start the game with a "child" card placed face up in his or her own play area.

On a player's turn, he or she draws one card from the face-down draw pile. If the card is a dragon's tail, the player may place it next to the child card; if not, the card is discarded. Once a tail card has been placed, future draws of a dragon's body or dragon's head are allowed to be (and must be) played next to the tile, whereas future draws of a tail are then discarded. Drawing a dragon's head completes a dragon.

After completing a dragon, the player, on his or her next turn, make take another child card, if any remain, and begin anew the process of attempting to create the longest dragon.

If the draw pile is exhausted, the discard pile is shuffled to form a new draw pile.

The game ends when sufficient cards have been drawn and placed such that no further legal plays can be made. The winner is the player who created the longest dragon.

Children's game to keep them occupied on a long car journey. Each child id dealt some cards (the number could vary depending on the time available). Then it is a simple mechanic of spotting one of the items on the cards in their hand. First to spot all the cards in their hand, wins.

The world's most famous capital cities didn't just appear overnight. It took careful planning, resources, and time. Now, new countries seek to build great capitals of their own, and you are challenged to create a city unlike any other – but with each new era comes new challenges, and you must be prepared to make important decisions. The winning player will earn the right to host the next World Expo, but that's a prize reserved for only the most prestigious city.

The Capitals is a city-building game unlike any other, featuring new and creative game mechanisms. Cities take many years to build, and The Capitals requires players to plan ahead to create their vision. Playing over three eras, from Victorian to Modern Day, players are challenged to build a capital city that can compete with the world's best but also stand the test of time. With over one hundred unique buildings to construct, no two cities will ever be identical.

What story will your city tell?

item.description:
Objective: be the first to reach finish line
learn traffic signs/rules
 - acting by turn -
roll the die - ending on a marked/numbered space follow instruchtions printed cover inside
remarks:
pewter meeples - late 40's/early 50's
Spinner game from McLoughlin Brothers. Spin the spinner and look for the results.

Spair is a very simple two players game playable with two Shibumi game systems. It uses two 4×4 boards, and two whole sets of balls.

Rules
The board starts empty. Two players take turns placing a ball of one color on the first board (called A), and then a ball of another color on the second board (called B), according to the following rules:
1) a ball may be placed on a board if its color is different from the color of the ball that has been placed on the same board in the previous turn and
2) a player must place a ball of the color not placed by the opponent in the previous turn.

Balls may be placed either on empty board holes or stacking on 2x2 platforms of existing balls.

A player wins when a full line of any single color is made, orthogonally or diagonally, on any level on his board: board B for the first player and board A for the second player.

Lines on the 4x4 (board) level must be of length 4, lines on the 3x3 level must be of length 3, and lines on the 2x2 level must be of length 2.

A promotional card game from Kellogg's.

A set collecting game with everyone playing at once. You call out cards you have available to swap (but not the colour) and you try to do a deal with a player who is calling out a letter you need (but, of course, it might be the wrong colour but you don't know that until you add the card to your hand.

When you have a set of three cards (that spell POP) you shout out "Pop!" and lay down the set face-up. The game stops whilst your set is checked as valid and then starts again.

The winner is the first player to lay down all their cards in valid sets.

Really, this is a simpler form of Pit.

A playful novel game that will allow you to shape your strategies in humor and friendliness. You will find Asian natural elements: Wood, Fire, Earth, Metal, Water and Air. All these elements are connected through two cycles ancestral "Shen" (lead) and "Ke" (control). The game levels are represented by belt color (yellow, orange, green, blue and red): Everyone, beginner or advanced player, can participate.

Players tell the story with playing cards and must react and interupt for other players' stories. The goal is to be the first to play all your cards on the table

3.6 International is a game of thirty-six cards plus three jokers. Each card has a color, tens digit and units digit. The goal is to reconstruct six families of maps showing the same characteristics.

To do this, you ask a card from opponent. But it is allowed to lie. If You are in doubt, You may ask to see the hand of the target. There will be a penalty of three cards for the liar or for you if he didn't lie.

SICILY is the first game of the collection History & Legends, set between the centuries V B.C. and the IIIrd A.D.. Strategy, diplomacy and economy are combined in it, allowing to recreate the wars between Carthaginians, Greeks and Romans to get the control of the mentioned island.

It is a boardgame where can take part up to 4 players. It is structured in years, each one with its four seasons: spring, summer, autumn and winter. The game mechanics are very elaborated and allows to apply great variety of strategies. Nevertheless, learn to play is so easy and, in a few minutes, raw players can defend alone. The actions in every phase are very rapid, so games can last from 1 to 5 hours according to the select scene and it decided that the players are.

SICILY contains a great carton board and tokens, color rules, plastic miniatures, events and secret aims cards, etc... In these moments, it is only available in the language of Cervantes (spanish), but it also will be published the corresponding version in the language of Shakespeare (english).


SICILIA es el primer juego de la colección Historia y Leyendas, ambientado entre los siglos V antes de Cristo y el III después de Cristo. En él se combinan estrategia, diplomacia y economía, permitiendo recrear las guerras entre cartagineses, griegos y romanos para hacerse con el control de dicha isla.

Se trata de un juego de tablero en el que pueden participar hasta 4 jugadores por partida. Se estructura en años, cada uno con sus cuatro temporadas: primavera, verano, otoño e invierno. La mecánica de juego está muy elaborada y permite aplicar gran variedad de estrategias. Sin embargo, aprender a jugar es sencillo y en pocos minutos los jugadores novatos pueden defenderse solos. Las acciones en cada fase son muy rápidas, por lo que las partidas pueden durar de 1 a 5 horas según el escenario escogido y lo decididos que sean los participantes.

SICILIA contiene un gran tablero de cartón, un reglamento a todo color, miniaturas de plástico, fichas de cartón, cartas de sucesos y de objetivos secretos. En estos momentos solamente está disponible en el idioma de Cervantes (castellano), pero dentro de poco también publicaremos la versión correspondiente en el idioma de Shakespeare (inglés).

item.description:
Hop down the rabbit trail to pick some garden fresh veggies. But watch out! Pickles and Digger are in a playful mood. Sneak past them to bring home fresh veggies for a delicious treat!

On your turn, roll the 3 colored dice and resolve them in order:

- Blue Die: Shows which section of the garden Pickles the Farmer will visit this turn. Any rabbits in that section lose the Veggie Tile they're carrying, and must go to the farmhouse until their next turn.
 - Orange Die: Shows how many spaces Digger the Dog will move around the dog run on his turn. If the dog enters a forest where a Rabbit Pawn is waiting, that rabbit drops their veggies and must return to their rabbit hole until their next turn.
 - White Die: Move your Rabbit Pawn up to the number of spaces you rolled. You may stop to pick up a Veggie Tile then continue on until the number of spaces you rolled are used up. But remember...sometimes it's safer to move fewer spaces than you rolled.

Collect veggies (carrots, radishes, lettuce, or eggplants) for points -- if they're from another rabbit's corner of the garden you earn bonus points!

WHAT THEY'LL LEARN: Sequencing, Risk vs Reward, Early Counting & Math

Draw 12 tiles and place them behind your screen. Create sequences of 3 or more tiles. First person to use all of their tiles wins the game!

During the first round, each player must open by creating a new sequence. After the first round of play, players may create more new sequences or place individual tiles.

A new sequence can be created vertically or horizontally -- in crossword fashion -- but the value between tiles in a sequence must always be equal, such as 3-7-11 (spaced by 4) or 5-12-19 (spaced by 7). TIME WARP: If a player plays a new sequence which contains one tile of each color (red, blue, and yellow), all opponents draw one random tile from the cloth bag.

After their opening turn, players may add new tiles to the front or end of an existing sequence (including another player's sequence), as long as the spacing already established for that sequence is followed. Players may also insert two or more new tiles inside an existing sequence, altering the spacing to a new value between tiles.

Players play as many tiles as possible on their turn, and if they can't play at least one tile they must draw one from the cloth bag. The first player to place all their tiles wins!

WHAT THEY'LL LEARN: Sequencing, Patterning

Time to hit the open road! Visit scenic locations around the USA. Earn a point for each Destination you visit, and bonuses for collecting sets!

Each player starts with 4 Destination Cards, chooses one of them for a starting location, and places their car pawn on that city. On a player's turn, their car pawn can move three times using the roads or airlines. Events or Bonus Cards may give additional moves. Announce the names of each city you visit, so other players are aware which cities have been visited.

Each time a player stops in a city shown on a "public card" or one of their Destination Cards, they add that card face-up in their scoring area and move up the scoring track.

Always pay attention during other players' turns. If another player visits a city that matches one of the cards in your hand, ask them to send you a postcard! They score the card you were holding, but you receive a card from the Postcard Deck, which is also worth a point.

After finishing your turn, draw cards from the Destination Deck to replenish your hand back to 3 cards. If an Event Card is revealed while drawing, follow the instructions on the card first, then draw a new Destination Card to replace it.

Any time a player completes a set of 3 Destination Cards and/or Postcards of the same color, they receive a Bonus Card. These cards provide bonus points or special abilities that will help you advance.

WHAT THEY'LL LEARN: Geography, Strategy, State Facts


 Sequel to: Let's Jet

Air combat in the 1980's. An extremely simple game (one tiny page of rules) in which the players command the air assets of sectors of a military front. Each has, typically, 15 to 30 planes of various types to allocate secretly to one of four missions (Scramble Ready, Ground Attack, Offensive Air Superiority, Defensive Air Superiority). The allocations are then revealed, and the players determine how many ground attacks succeeded and how many planes were shot down or damaged. Successful ground attacks score 5 victory points, downed planes 2 each.

Scenarios are provided for Germany (U.S. or U.K./Germans vs. USSR), the Mediterranean and the Middle East (Israel vs. Syria).

name.value: ANTS! The Battle For The Backyard Has Begun!

item.description:
ANTS! The Battle For The Backyard Has Begun is a card and modular board game where each player takes command of the black or red Ant Queen and battles for ultimate control of the backyard!

Every playthrough will be different with a large hexagonal play area that changes each time you play! Random events can impact gameplay by causing board pieces to shift unexpectedly or even be destroyed!

Players build armies of ants with various bonuses to go and take out the rival queen. Action cards offer the ability to ally with spiders, wasps, catterpillers, and hornets to aid in your conquest but beware; there is a large glass eye in the sky that fries your warriors without notice!

Build your subterranean base as well and attack your opponent at will in this game of skill and strategy! Each base will be different and no play-through will be the same!

Word Rummikub, with cards instead of tiles. Players use their hand of cards to make words Rummy-style. In addition to laying new words, a player may rearrange any word to make a new word with the same letters plus at least one new letter.

Points are scored for words but if you have more than one word in front of you, only the longest counts (1 point per letter).

The winner is the one with the most points after a set number of deals.

name.value: L'histoire de France en un tour de cartes!

item.description:
Card game for children aged around 10 years old. There are rules to four games using the cards.

Game 1: Qui, quoi, quand?
A game for 2 players
The cards are shuffled and placed in a stack in the centre of the table. On a turn, the player takes the top card and looks at the picture and the text on the other side of the card. From this, he or she must guess the correct historical period for the card e.g. Léonard de Vinci would be a La Renaissance card. Then check the summary card. If correct, he scores a point. If not, the card is discarded and the opponent has a turn. When all the cards have been used, the one with the most points, wins.

Game 2: L'ordre chronologique
Cards are dealt out evenly. The remaing cards are placed in a stack. A card is revealed and the player must lay a card that goes immediately before the date on that card or just after it. If you cannot play a card, you must pass and take a card from the stack and add it to your hand. The first player to use all their cards, wins.

Game 3: Qui suis-je?
Stack all the cards with only the picture side showing. Each player, in turn, takes the top card and tries to name the event, person, etc. The card is then turned over to reveal the text. If the player is correct, he keeps the card. If not, it is discared. The player with the most cards when the stack is emptied, wins.

Game 4: 9 Familles
The cards are colour coded so a straightforward version of 7 Familles/Happy Families can be played. Each set collected is worth one point for every card in that set. When all the sets are played out, the winner is the one with the most points.

Card game with a lot of bluffing involved.

Rules (as written on the back of the box)

The object of the game is, by bluffing, to be the first player to dispose of all his cards.
The cards are shuffled and dealt to all the players. The player to the left of the dealer begins by placing one card face down onto the centre of the table and names its picture, for example saying "flower". The next player puts a card on top of it also saying "flower", this is when the bluffing comes in. Each player in his turn has to claim to lay the same picture as that which was started with whether he has one or not. Play continues in this way until the call comes back to the player who started the round. He calls again the name of the picture he started with and lays a card. This is the end of that round. The next player starts a new round by placing a card on top of the cards already on the table (if any) and names the same or a different picture.
Any time a player thinks another player is bluffing he may challenge him. If he is in fact bluffing and has not laid the card he said, he has to pick up all the cards on the table and add them to his hand. If he was not bluffing the challenger has to pick up all the cards.

Objective: be the first making the fastest lap
 - moving by turn - 
each player moves according 1d6 roll; ending on a marked space follow instructions printed on cover inside.
Last space must be reached with matching number - surplus movement points push you backwards.
remarks: 
republished 1955 - still the same artist (board) Scheer (prename unknown)

Party game. Each guest is given a card of clues and told that the answer must end in the letter O. During the evening, they should try to answer as many correctly as they can. The player with the most correct, wins.

Trivia game about history (mainly about revolutions) of France.

In his turn player spin the spinner with 2 choises: years 1968 or 2008. Question card is taken from that category. It has one minute to tell what You think and then opponents tell us are they were satisfied or not. If a majority yes, you win the points indicated on the box where it had fallen.

Winner is the player who reaches predetermined number of points.

Some example questions:
"The great struggles that everyone does not care, tell","The signs of the revolution, which were you believe."

Each player has four small pawns and a larger pawn called Ciblux.
In his turn player roll dice and move one of his smaller pawn accordingly.

There are 3 areas in the game board to move.:
- A white area where small pieces can move "with impunity".
- A yellow box called 'danger zone' where small pieces can be ejected by the Ciblux of the opponent.
- A central area which is the goal for small pieces.

The object is to bring all his small pawns to the central area first. Alternative end is if player catches with Ciblux opponent's smaller pawn and wins.

Voting game where player has 2 minutes to answer a question or prove something etc. If time stops other players vote is Your answer satisfied them. If Yes You score a point. 
Who reaches a predetermined score wins the game.

Some card examples: "Invent a sence that doesn't make any sence","Make us believe You are a Kangoroo", "What is priceless in You opinion"

Objective: be the first to enter space '100'
 - moving by turn -
move according rolled die - ending on a marked (red) space follow instructions...
remarks:
published in GDR early 50's

Spava is a game for the Shibumi set, made as an entry for Shibumi Challenge.

Two players, White and Black, take turns adding either a ball of their colour or a neutral red ball.

A player wins by completing a line of length L of their colour on any LxL level. A player loses by completing a line of length L-1 on any LxL level. Lines can be orthogonal or diagonal but must contain at least two balls.

Included in the Shibumi Rule Book

Soft cover:

http://www.lulu.com/shop/cameron-browne-and-nestor-romeral-andres/shibumi-rule-book/paperback/product-18940123.html

Downloadable PDF:

http://www.nestorgames.com/rulebooks/SHIBUMI_EN.pdf

item.description:
Game description from the publisher:

Beneath the mountain called Goblins' Rock, the goblins have been mining for centuries. They have dug deeper and deeper. Their precious ore is running out and the taskmasters are getting BORED!

So in order to pass the time, the taskmasters have taken to racing their underlings into a...PIT OF FIRE! (Underlings are expendable, after all.) It is agreed that secretly choosing their favorites would be best and the race would end when the "winner" falls into the pit. Oh, and there should be gambling. You know, just to keep it interesting!

Go Goblin, Go! is a light, standalone racing and gambling board game. You secretly pick three of the racing goblins and you get points based on where they finish. You manipulate their movement, so you have some control over where they finish. Just don't be first. The first goblin to fall into the pit "wins", but they don't get any points.

Each player roll the dice and move around the board to bring together the different ingredients of the pancake batter.
Once "milk shed", "flour weighing" and "broken eggs" are collected it's time the frying pan in hand to be the cleverest to blow up pancakes in a limited time.
But beware! There can be surprise on some squares on the board.

Winner is the player to make 15 pancakes.first.

Contents:

 game board, 
 4 colored pawns, 
 1 die, 
 1 hourglass
 12 cards ingredients
 double-sided skillet,
 a pancake, 
 crepe 60 tokens.

1950's Marx O Matic children's basketball game - Tin litho.

Metal Base of the game is 22" long X 13" wide and the metal back is 11" Tall.

Game comes with an automatic scoreboard. Players use the shooter, attached to base, to lob balls into the net.

The shooter base has a counter that keeps track of 12 shots and then rings the bell when complete.

Serpent Stones is a card game which claims to be based on a lost Aztec abstract game called Itzcoatl, a game which is not recorded anywhere else.

As head priest of an Aztec warrior house, you must command a specialized team of Aztec warriors in ritual combat on the battlefield to satisfy the gods. Drawing on the power of teotl from your temple stone, your warriors can wield specialized nahualli animal attacks to strike or capture opposing warriors standing in your team's way of capturing your opponent's temple stone. The gods may show you favor by giving you an advantage during battle, but will it be you or your opponent that quenches their insatiable blood thirst today?

Players of Serpent Stones sit on opposite sides of a game board featuring seven staggered rows of Serpent Stones and take turns drawing a card and playing/discarding a card from an initial hand of five cards. Serpent Stones features three types of cards:


 Warrior cards, which are played on the Serpent Stones to build your Aztec warrior team
 Nahualli cards, which strike or capture opposing warrior cards
 Teotl cards, which are "god" cards that can give a player some tactical advantage during gameplay


A player wins when either he captures his opponent's temple stone by placing a warrior card on it or he forces his opponent to suffer the "Wrath of Tezcatlipoca", a fancy Aztecian way of saying the opponent ran out of cards.

item.description:
Action board game. The board has 16 holes in it. The player loads a spring device and places it on the table, as far back as he wishes, and catapults a ball onto the board. If it settles into one of the holes, a score of 2 to 10 points will be scored. The one with the most points when the game ends, wins.

The spring device will cause the player to experiment. Two factors are involved - how far back to reach the board and how much to hold the device down before releasing it. It must be easy to over-shoot or under-shoot the board.

Strange noises are heard from the Mad Mansion of Doctor Doom. Clouds of all colors come out of the chimney, and people tell weird stories about crazy creatures seen in the forest around the mansion. Help Doctor Doom finish his extravagant experiments to create the world's wackiest and craziest creatures ever seen!

In Crazy Creatures of Dr. Doom (a.k.a. Dr. Gloom in the U.S. release), all players try to get rid of their cards as cards in hand score penalty points at the end of a round. The player with the fewest penalty points at the end of the game wins and becomes Doctor Doom's new apprentice!

item.description:
Long, long ago there was a mysterious village called Blackmore situated in a beautiful forest with giant trees and small forest roads. The town was home to a group of witches, and they lived their lives full of magic, sending out dark magic spells. Over all those years, however, no one was able to control the Witches Wheel, until now...

In The Witches of Blackmore, you try to control the Witches Wheel as long and as often as you can. Every witch that you catch in your tricks gives you Magic Points, and whoever collects the most Magic Points wins and gains control of the Witches Wheel until the end of time.

name.value: Phineas and Ferb Funniest Card Game Ever!

item.description:
Goal: Players try to match the characters to the correct scene. The player with the most points from completed scenes when the last card is drawn wins.

The game comes with 2 decks of cards (68 blue-backed and 12 green-backed) plus 9 cardboard characters. To start the game players claim the characters one at a time and are dealt 3 blue cards. Then a green card is turned up. Players take turns drawing 1 blue card and playing 1 blue card. Here are the different types of cards in the game:


 Green-backed cards = These cards give special responsibilities to the player who holds Agent P or Dr. Doofenshmirtz. For example "Say 'Ahh, Perry the Platypus!' before you start your turn. If you forget, you turn is over!" These cards also give the indicated player an extra penalty or bonus. For example "You may play 1 extra card." A new green-backed card is flipped over and takes effect whenever the Agent P or Dr. Doofenshmirtz character moves to another player.
 Blue-backed Character Cards = These cards move the characters around. For instance "Take 1 character from another player."
 Blue-backed Power Cards = These cards give you special card-play powers. For instance "Take 1 random card from each player."
 Blue-backed Challenge Cards = These cards allow you to do weird challenges against other players. For instance "Challenge another player to a game of Rock-Paper-Scissors. If you win, take up to 3 random cards from the other player.
 Blue-backed Scene Cards = These cards are how you score points. If you have the character(s) shown on the card you can play it for the number of points indicated on the card. For instance the "Unfair Science Fair" card is worth 10 points if you currently hold Baljeet.
 Blue-backed Special Cards = The Mom card forces everyone to discard everything and draw 3 new cards. The 50 Bonus Points card gives 50 points to the player holding it at the end of the game.

name.value: Phineas And Ferb 104 Days Of Summer Board Game

item.description: With Phinneas & Ferb 104 Days of Summer Board Game every day is a different adventure! The Goal of the game is to have a great time with your friends and earn the most 'Summer Fun' points to 'Win'! There are Mini games that challenge players' dexterity and skill mixed in with plain old luck. Each day of the week features a different activity type from 'Mental Monday' to 'Speedy Saturday'. Themed, multi purpose props bring elements of the show to life and are used in different and surprising ways during the game.

item.description:
It is the 21st Century! Time for something other than checkers.
 Take area control and piece taking to a whole new level. There is no jumping, no king this or king that, just dominance!

The board starts empty and you must dynamically "spawn" in your pieces!

This is a new kind of game for you to play with family and friends. Dominance is easy enough for players of all ages, it is fast, giving you the chance to play best out of three in one night, yet still intense enough to challenge the competitive adults in your life.

Ever shifting area control and the ability to bring new pieces onto the game board from any side, give you a much different experience than other abstract games you might have played before.

The game can be used to teach the many different facets of tactical and strategic play. This game fits into the middle ground between checkers and chess. There is not much to learn in the way of rules. But there is a lot to learn about how to win!

Play it Online @ tabletopia.com

Created at Global Game Jam 2012

Emerging and adapting, newly formed life evolves on a decaying creature.

The goal in Saprobiont is to accumulate the most Biomass for your species to avoid extinction. Players earn Biomass by controlling Zones as well as by other species-specific means. The player with the most Biomass at the end of the game wins.

The species are:

The Swarm - Places tokens twice each turn. Gets a biomass bonus when controlling four or more zones.

The Shredder - Gets a Biomass bonus for killing enemies

The Canker - Placing tokens in a zone converts enemy tokens. Gains a Biomass bonus for of their tokens at end of the game.

The Ampulex - Placing in a zone, moves enemy tokens out forcing new conflict. Earn bonus biomass for tokens killed in this way.

The Amanda Knox Game is a board game based on the true events of November 1, 2007 in Perugia, Italy. Each player takes on the role of an individual present at the crime scene and pursues variable, hidden goals.

Decisions are made in real time. A sand timer is moved along a time track at the bottom of the board advancing fifteen minutes each turn. A die roll moves the player around the four-bedroom ground-floor apartment depicted on the game board.

Players must make choices that may alter or recreate historical events.

A small metal ball is hit by a spinning batter. The hole it falls into names the result of the play. The game probably commemorates the ST. LOUIS CARDINALS Baseball team and was made by The Measuregraph Co. of ST. LOUIS, MO. This game is shown in the BASEBALL GAMES BOOK BY MARK COOPER, M.D. OF SCHIFFER BOOKS.

From Topps' website: WWE Power Chipz is ready to become the latest hit with WWE's legion of fans! With over 140 Chipz to collect, look for your favorite WWE superstars including John Cena, The Miz, Rey Mysterio, Divas, and WWE Legends. Gamers will have 6 action-packed games to play with a special magnetic powerball. Roll your powerball over your Chipz, and watch to see how many you can get to stick. The more Chipz that stick, the more points you earn! Plus, special Ruby, Silver, and Gold Chipz give you bonuses!

In this game you lay out different WWE Power Chipz on the ground and take turns rolling a magnetic ball. Each WWE Power Chipz poker style chip features a wrestler and a star power. After rolling the magnetic ball, you claim whichever chips are stuck to the ball.

After all of the chips have been collected, you add up your total scores and whoever has the highest score is the winner.

Miniature Rules for World War Two Naval Warfare

Scale:

tactical turn = 10 minutes
strategic turns = 40 minutes
4 cm = one nautical mile 
1 model = one ship or four or five aircraft.

Player's take the role of squadron or fleet commander. One die per battery. If a hit is scored, another die is rolled to determine the damage. AA fire is handled a bit differently with each ship having a number of Light AA, and AA dice dependent upon armament. Within certain restrictions these dice may be allocated to more than one enemy flight per turn as required.

Radar can be useful to detect enemy forces. Once forces come within visual range, firing is likely to commence. Damage rates may seem high. It is quite possible for a destroyer to be sunk in a single round of combat. Ships suffer damage which includes degradation of firepower, speed, or C3 systems.

C3 systems and formation command are simulated with each formation's flagship maneuvering and any ships in formation with it will conform. Ships not in the flagship’s formation roll a die to determine whether they may maneuver.

ref: http://mcmdgames.blogspot.com/2012/01/ww2-all-at-sea review.html

Paging all interns! New patients have arrived in the ER, and you want to fight — whether fairly or not – against the other interns to prove that you're the right person for the open doctor position at the hospital.

In Hospital Rush, the player interns compete against one another to be the first with ten prestige points. Each round, players place two pawns on various fair and unfair actions, with unfair actions possibly being punished later by other players. During the game, the players collect medicine, learn new skills, take exams, and treat patients. May the best (or most devious) intern win!

item.description:
The game board shows a map of London. Players roll a die and move through the city, trying to reach the famous sites (especially those two whose cards they drew at the beginning and which are marked). Additionally, taxis, buses and the tube can be used to get around more quickly, but they have to be paid for in travel chips. When a player reaches a site, s/he is asked a question. If answering correctly, the site card can be discarded and a new travel chip is drawn. When reaching an unmarked site, they can earn a new site card (if that belongs to someone else, it can be "stolen"). 
When a player can reach both sites they drew at the beginning and gain two more site cards and return to their starting location, s/he wins the game.

Questions come in two difficulty levels, as the game is designed for language learning. So the difficulty does not refer to the knowledge needed to answer the question, but to the English speaking ability.

The game board shows a map of Berlin. Players roll a die and move through the city, trying to reach the famous sites (especially those two whose cards they drew at the beginning and which are marked). Additionally, taxis, buses and the tube can be used to get around more quickly, but they have to be paid for in travel chips. When a player reaches a site, s/he is asked a question. If answering correctly, the site card can be discarded and a new travel chip is drawn. When reaching an unmarked site, they can earn a new site card (if that belongs to someone else, it can be "stolen"). 
When a player can reach both sites they drew at the beginning and gain two more site cards and return to their starting location, s/he wins the game.

Each card has two questions, one about German, one a trivia question, so language learners can play it with non-language learners as well.

item.description:
Greek Salad is a 2-6 player card game for ages 6+

Help the chefs prepare a Greek Salad! Obey their orders, add veggies and seasonings, mix the ingredients and the salad is done! The first player to get rid of all of his cards is the winner.

The object of the game is to be the first to get rid of all of your cards. You accomplish this by playing a card with a more of one type of ingridient that the last card played. For example if the last card played had 2 peppers, 4 tomatoes & 1 peice of feta cheese the next card played must contain either 5 tomatoes, 3 peppers or 2 pieces of feta cheese, if you can't play a card you must draw a card.

There are special 'seasoning' cards which skip alayers turn and mix up the discard pile. There are also two more special cards: the chef allows you to declare an ingredient you either want or don't want and the subsequent players must abide and the salad bowl card which reverses the logic of the rules so that for the example above with the peppers, tomatoes and cheese you would need a card with less than one of those ingredients. First one to discard all his cars wins.

item.description:
An abstract strategy game created for the 2012 Global Game Jam.

The game is played on a circular board, without a set number of "spaces", but rather the game pieces also make up the number of spaces, and as pieces are captured, the board will shrink until one player has only one piece left, and they are the winner.

Players have two movement cards laying visible in front of them, and choose how many spaces to move their "king" pieces by flipping one of the cards (thus changing the number of spaces they may potentially move their next turn). The game can be changed subtly by choosing a different set of movement cards to play with each game.

name.value: Mad Hatters: The Mad-Cap Feel It and Find It Game

item.description: Following instructions from the Mad Hatter cards, players attempt to remove the corresponding object from the brim of their own cap (special caps included). However, players are allowed to identify each object only by touch--no looking is allowed. If a player can correctly name the object, only then may they remove it. If a player removes the wrong object, they must put it back on their cap and pick up another object to add to their cap. The object is to be the first player to identify and correctly remove eight objects.

Each player uses 6 men, but puts only one on the board at a time. He moves each turn as far as spun with the arrow, doing as directed on the spaces at which he stops. As soon as this man is drawn into the whirlpool, or center, it is lost and another is started.

The player holding out the longest wins.

An old swedish wordgame based on 40 sixsided wooden pieces that can be fit to each other into a long row. On each side there are a word written. By combining different pieces and put them toghether you form sentences. There are different way of playing and scoring. The easiest way is that each player in one minute tries to form an as long sentence as possibly. After you have done a sentence you can change the meaning by twisting the wooden pieces and score extra points.

In his turn, the player rolls the 3 x d12 dice and keeps what he wants. Then he may re-roll twice any dice.
The goal is score points for combinations:
f.e. pair scores 40 points, straigh scores 100 points, sum of 13 scores 250 points, three of a kind scores 500 points etc.
Game ends if any player has points 700 or more. He is the winner.
But if somebody gets combination sum of 13 including pair he wins the game immediately.

Contents:

 3 x d12
 45 chips

Spyramid is a game for the Shibumi set that explores a new victory condition.

The board starts empty.

Two players (white and black) alternate turns either:

- Placing a ball of their colour on an empty hole or platform.

- Removing a ball of their colour that supports at most 1 ball on the level above and placing it in another valid location, except above balls dropped. Balls may drop as a result of ball removing.

Victory condition:

First player creating the 5 vertices of a pyramid of any size wins (example: 4 board corners and the apex). The pyramid can be facing up or down (apex above or below the base). In case of two or more pyramids of different colours being created, the player that did the last move wins.

Ties seem to be possible.

Note: The pyramid can be of any size (2x2,3x3,4x4). There are 14 pyramids facing up and 5 small (2x2) pyramids facing down.

Variant: The pyramid can be also rotated 45 degrees when viewed from above.

Included in the Shibumi Rule Book

Soft cover:

http://www.lulu.com/shop/cameron-browne-and-nestor-romeral-andres/shibumi-rule-book/paperback/product-18940123.html

Downloadable PDF:

http://www.nestorgames.com/rulebooks/SHIBUMI_EN.pdf

item.description:
The year is 1922. A pandemic is sweeping the globe. At first, scientists believe it to be yet another wave of the Spanish Flu. In the disease’s early stages, patients present with high fever, vomiting, and weakness. Quickly, the Spanish Flu theory comes under scrutiny. Patients all report having been attacked. Where the disease spreads violent crime seems to inexplicably rise. As outbreaks skyrocket, several studies conclusively prove the disease in not the dreaded Spanish Flu; it is something much worse. Late stage symptoms are found to include death, reanimation, superhuman strength, and an insatiable craving for human flesh.

After precious few years of peace, the nations of the world are returning once more to the trenches, united against a common foe. In Zombies & Zeppelins, 2-4 players lead the forces of humanity against hordes of the undead. Together, players must attempt to clear the numerous infested cities around the world. Should they fail, mankind will be swept away in a tide of the damned.

Zombies & Zeppelins is played on a game board depicting a map of the world which has been divided into 25 regions. The game uses a card-driven system to determine both the spread of the undead and humanity's military capacity. Player's must carefully manage their meager resources in combating the undead. Through clever maneuvering of their infantry, armor and artillery, and a little bit of luck, players might just be able to avert Armageddon.

Spoker is a game with random elements for the Shibumi game system. SHIBUMI MEETS POKER!

Equipment: the 4x4 Shibumi board and 10 balls of each color (white, black and red). Two players.

Rules

The board starts empty. Players take turns taking a ball at random, for example from an opaque bag, and placing it either on empty board holes or stacking on 2x2 platforms of existing balls.

When a player, with the ball just placed, has formed a visible winning group of balls (see below) he shows it and challenges the opponent, so also the other player takes at random a ball and places it trying to do a group of higher ranking.

The player with the higher ranking group wins the challenge and scores one point. If the two groups have the same ranking, each player scores one point. Obviously if the other player is not able to form a winning group he loses the challenge.
Winning groups can be in any level and also composed by balls placed in different levels. Between two groups of the same ranking, the winner (if exists) is the group with at least a ball at a higher level than the other group.

The game ends when the 30 balls pyramid is complete and the winner is the player with the highest score at the end of the game.
Apex ball can be used only to respond to a challenge, or to form a “straight flush”.

If the placement of a ball creates two or more winning groups, you must always consider the highest ranking group.

When a player has formed a “straight flush”, he wins immediately the game, regardless of the score.

WINNING GROUPS in ASCENDING RANKING ORDER

Three of three kinds: a straight line of three touching balls of different colors, in any order, orthogonal or one on top of the other (when they are in different levels);
Flush three: a straight line of three touching balls of the same color, orthogonal or one on top of the other (when they are in different levels);
Full house: a five balls pyramid formed by two touching balls of the same color and two touching balls of another color in the platform, and a ball of one of that two colors on the top;
Flush four: a straight line of four touching balls of the same color, orthogonal or one on top of the other (when they are in different levels);
Straight flush: a five balls pyramid of the same color.

item.description:
Aion is a strategic game of tile laying for two players based on the ancient symbol of the Ouroboros or Aion. The Aion is a powerful alchemical symbol of rebirth and represents the infinite transmutability of matter. During the game, players will play tiles representing alchemical runes and materials to the board while trying to form looped serpents to score points.

Aion was the winning entry of the Ottawa jam site in the Concept category of the 2012 Global Game Jam.

Game description from the publisher:

Aeroplanes: Aviation Ascendant explores the dawn of commercial aviation, an exciting era between 1919 and 1939. Experience the difficulties and triumphs of commercial airlines in Europe, pioneering airports and service in continental Europe and around the world!

Aviation spurred the growth of intercontinental travel, and airlines struggled to dominate the regions of the globe that they served.

Rapid technological advances in planes play a vital role in this development as you compete to purchase newer more efficient aeroplanes, build airports, and move passengers around the globe. Earn bonuses and prestige for being the first to fly to North or South America, and win by maintaining the most airports around the world and by running your airline profitably.

Can you balance your investment in aeroplanes, customer service, and routes well enough to become the premier airline of the era? The fate and future of air travel lies within your hands!

link.value: Mayfair Games' Limited Edition Promo Expansion Set #19

item.description:
The oppressive jungle heat causes small beads of sweat to trickle down your brow. Or is it the fear? The enemy is close; you can feel it. Maybe he's around the next bend in the trail, waiting to bushwhack the tired or unwary. Does that bush hide a machine gun? Tunnel entrance under that clump of leafs? Maybe there's a sniper lying in wait up in that tree? Your squad looks to you for leadership, for knowledge, for guts. Do you have what it takes? Can you lead them and get them home alive?

Or are you headed for disaster, just another Freakin' New Guy in The Nam?

FNG: Second Tour (FNG2T) is the second edition of FNG. We've streamlined the mechanics and kicked up the realism. FNG2T gives you what you need to run your grunts through infantry combat in Vietnam during 1967-1968.

Don't have an opponent? No problem! FNG: Second Tour also includes extensive solo mechanics so you can play against the game either by yourself or with friends all on the same side! FNG: Second Tour is designed to be played with one figure representing one man and in any figure scale you may already have. Artillery, airstrikes, helicopter gunships, Puff the Magic Dragon, bunkers, tunnels, and more. FNG: Second Tour has them all and much more.

FNG: Second Tour also includes a unique campaign system to carry your Star (your personal soldier) through an entire combat tour of exotic Vietnam. This campaign system not only generates your missions, but also your enemies, rewards for success and repercussions for failure, even the terrain in which you will play.

All this lets us guarantee that you'll never fight the exact same mission more than once.

As your campaign progresses, so does the experience and abilities of your troops. If you command well, some might even survive long enough to rotate home and be replaced by fresh FNGs. But, if you lead poorly you will see more than your share of body-bags.

So throw on your favorite 60's music, lock and load, and head out into the jungle. The enemy is waiting. Will you have the guts, or will you beÂ…just another FNG?

The oppressive jungle heat causes small beads of sweat to trickle down your brow. Or is it the fear?

The enemy is close; you can feel it. Maybe he's around the next bend in the trail, waiting to bushwhack the tired or unwary. Does that bush hide a machine gun? Tunnel entrance under that clump of leafs? Maybe there's a sniper lying in wait up in that tree?

Your squad looks to you for leadership, for knowledge, for guts. Do you have what it takes? Can you lead them and get them home alive?

Re-implements:

 FNG

RECALL is designed to measure and improve your ability to recall information. RECALL does not require exception memory capabilities but rather relies on organizational techniques to help you organize information to improved memory.

How does RECALL work? There are six thematic game boards with different pictures on each board. There are eighty tiles with pictures on each board. There are eighty tiles with pictures of familiar objects printed one each tile. The object of the game is to place these tiles face down on the game board, and use cues from the images on the board to the develop associations that assist you in recalling which object is on each tiles as you turn them over. You can start with just a few tiles and work up to recalling the objects on dozens of tiles.

RECALL can be played as a single-player activity, as a cooperative game, or as a competitive game. It can also be used as a great learning tool for kids.

You will be surprised how well your organizational techniques work. You will see improvement in your recall capability immediately!

For competitive play two or more players can play the game competitively. Each player takes a turn selecting, placing, and turning over Object Tiles. The number of correct Object Tiles is recorded and the player with the most correctly placed tiles wins.

To play cooperatively all players collectively decide on where to place Object Tiles.

This is a 3-player game, using 3 colours (Black, White & Red), but with no colour representing any one player. It is played using a standard Shibumi set.
In essence, it is a simple connect-3 game. The winner is the player that connects 3 of any colour in a visible straight line (“visible” meaning that, for instance, a 3-in-a-row going through the middle of the pyramid, with stones all round, blocking one or more stones from sight, is not a win).

The board starts empty. Each player places 2 stones each turn, in this order:
P.1: B, W
P.2: R, B
P.3: W, R
Passing is not allowed, and the stones must be played in this specific order. There is no removal of stones in this game.

That is the full extent of the rules. A draw can indeed occur.

This game was created in response to the Shibumi Challenge.

Included in the Shibumi Rule Book

Soft cover:

http://www.lulu.com/shop/cameron-browne-and-nestor-romeral-andres/shibumi-rule-book/paperback/product-18940123.html

Downloadable PDF:

http://www.nestorgames.com/rulebooks/SHIBUMI_EN.pdf

Have you ever wanted to poop in someone’s yard? Well here is your chance. In Dog Poop, it is your objective to dig holes, trample flowers, knock over the garbage, and find mystery goodies in other back yards. Naturally, you are trying to do all this while keeping your own yard as clean as possible. There are special things you can get like a scoop to clean your yard or the cat to draw other dogs away. Get in touch with your inner poodle or wolf hound as the case may be. All in all, this game is a bunch of laughs for everyone involved.

Aliens are attacking! Invading Sector V!

The player must maneuver their Defender craft and shoot down advancing aliens as they descend from the sky. You have limited repair resources and ammunition for your laser cannon is in short supply. Eliminate all the Invaders before they either successfully land, or destroy the Defenser which occupies the bottom of the playfield

A solo play Space Invaders style game using the full Shibumi game set.

Minions! is a strategic race through the woods!
You control a force of creatures and race against your opponent to get 3 creatures to the opposite side of the board. 
You can summon Wolves, squash Frogs and use magical Elves to push Turtles into fire. 
Each creature has unique, interactive abilities that create different possibilities.
Minions! is essentially an abstract game of movement, with no dice and very little chance. However, unlike many abstract games, there are many different ways to play, and creative strategy is the key to success.

name.value: Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer DVD Game

item.description:
Help Rudolph, Santa, Hermey the Elf, and Clarice save Christmas while reliving favorite moments from the classic TV special, Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer®. Enjoy fun mini-games and on-screen puzzles as you wind around the themed game board rescuing Misfit Toys from Bumble the Abominable Snow Monster. Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer The DVD Game is sure to go down in history and become your family's must-play game every holiday season!

A powerful storm has scattered the Misfit Toys all around the North Pole and Santa needs your help collecting them! Gather the Misfit Toys to help Santa make his delivery on Christmas Eve. The players race to collect the Misfit Toys before Bumble the Abominable Snow Monster can find them. If any player collects three different-colored Misfit Toys before Bumble collects any six toys, that player wins the game.

An especially nice promotional card game from 1915, published by a paint producer (still active nearly 100 years later).

Each player tries to collect sets of the same numbered card. They ask for cards from other players (which must be handed over) but if you are unsuccessful in your search then you end your turn by drawing a card. Once a set is collected, it is placed in front of the player who completed this task. Eventually, all sets will be collected and the player with the most sets, wins.

Each card is an advert for products at the time. The products are;
Pompeian Night Cream and other cosmetics
Kelly-Springfield Tires and Tubes
Several different Willys-Overland vehicles
Post cereals
Welch's Punch, Lemonade, others
Beech-Nut Chewing Gum, Peanut Butter and Bacon. (Bacon!!)
Knox Gelatin desserts
Perfection Oil Cook stoves, ovens, heaters
Western Electric, Phones, Irons, washing machines
Libby's Hawaiian Pineapple, evaporated milk, fruits
Ingersoll Dollar , Junior, Midget and Eclipse Watches
Men's and Women's Walk-Over shoes.
Sherwin-Williams SWP House Paint, varnish and wall paint.

I think that each publisher was given copies of the game to sell or give away to their respective customers and/or staff. Comes in a red box.

link.value: Cambio y Bolsa, Mercado, y Miau

item.description:
A spin-off from the regular Subbuteo game of football. This was a Five-A-Side version, with an enclosed pitch so that the ball didn't always fly of the table. The mechanic of finger flicking the players remains the same.

Subbuteo is a classic finger-flicking soccer-simulation action game. It is played on a large cloth playing field called a "pitch", with teams of players that are represented by miniature men mounted on smooth round bases. The men are made to kick the ball by flicking their bases, which causes the men to slide around on the pitch, hitting the ball. The rules simulate nearly all details of a soccer game including ball possession and passing, throw-ins, goal kicks and corner kicks. There is even a large section in the rules devoted to fouling.

Two editions were produced. One with a folding pitch, the other with a solid pitch. Obviously, the solid pitch edition was in a box twice the size of the folding pitch edition.

Re-implements:

 Subbuteo

In Sails to Steam, a game for 2–5 players, each player takes charge of a different empire that it must lead to economic prosperity.

Starting with a small fleet comprised of a few meager sailboats and a canoe, players will build boats, settle colonies, and even found new countries in an effort to spread the influence of their mighty empire. As their influence and power expands, players must carefully gauge and react to the global economy created by their fellow players and attempt to leverage their advantages to push out other empires if they plan to become the mightiest empire.

link.value: Games by the Game Artisans of Canada

item.description:
Although there are a number of simulations for the dramatic events in Bavaria, Austrian and Spain in 1809, not much emphasis has been placed on conflicts in Prussia or in the Grand Duchy of Warsaw. However there were uprisings and armies in conflict in Eastern Europe, especially in the newly created Duchy of Warsaw.
La Bataille de Raszyn depicts the major battle between the VII Austrian Armeekorps and the Polish Forces defending Warsaw. The invasion force commanded by Archduke Ferdinand d’Este drives toward the capital of Poland being defended by General Poniatowski. Poniatowski decides to defend a crucial river crossing that has limited crossings and swampy ground.

The forces of Poniatowski are limited as much of the Polish forces are fighting in Spain. His available forces have excellent morale being highly motivated to defend a country once partitioned by Austrian, Prussia and Russia. A contingent of Saxons assist the Polish Army and scenarios add a variety of forces from neighboring areas.

D’ Este ‘Austrian’ Army is in fact made up of infantry from Hungary and Galician (Poland), with Grenz (border) troops and a sizable number of elite cavalry. Although this army outnumbers the forces of Poniatowski, it may lack the motivation and leadership of their counterpoints. The Austrian Army’s tactics include some of the recent reforms and traditional formations. Option rules and scenarios provide for a number of ‘what ifs” and fresh simulations

Each 20 minute turn starts with a Command Phase for both sides followed by the French Player sequence and then by the Prussian Player sequence. The sequence includes movement, cavalry charges, fire and melee. During each, morale plays a decisive role. This is a great one player on one player game that can be completed in an afternoon. In addition to the historical game there are two scenarios that vary the orders of battle and appearance times.
The original rules have been updated but not expanded to any extent. The original designers of the La Bataille Series believe the Premier Rules facilitate the most accurate and competitive play. The new Premier Rules are an update of the original rules but make it easier to find specific topics and includes some user requested rules such as command control.
Marshal Enterprises intends to publish a Napoleonic Grand Tactical Game every quarter. The games are free by down loading all the required documents at our website. Each specific title will have a Special Rules Package. Options include printing the map as a series of 11”x17” pages or as a two or one piece file. Instructions are included to make the unit and informational counters. Keep you r money for something important and have fun battling in Poland

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable
